metadata.titleEn: Wave dataset of southern Sri Lanka sea area (201309-201405)
metadata.description: This data set collects the wave tide level data of the southern sea area of Sri Lanka from September 2013 to October 2014. Sri Lanka is located in the core node of the "maritime Silk Road", which is the necessary node of our oil transportation lifeline. The wave observation data of this sea area is of great significance to understand the wave characteristics of this sea area and ensure the navigation safety of cargo ships and sea convoys. The data is obtained by the pressure sensor deployed on the seabed, and the data reliability is ensured by the quality control segments such as the removal of abnormal values. This data is of great significance to the analysis of marine disaster assessment, ship passing safety assessment and the study of wave characteristics in the sea area.

background: Ocean observational data are difficult to obtain but are needed for model validation and data assimilation. Specifically, wind and wave observational data are of great importance for the study of ocean surface mixing, local air–sea interactions, coastal hydrodynamic characteristics, sediment movement, monsoon studies, and ocean engineering. Matara is the southernmost city of the Indian Peninsula and is bordered by the northern Indian Ocean. The northern Indian Ocean is an important area for studying swells in the global wave climate, which persistently form in the southern oceans owing to the absence of land barriers (Alves, 2006). Many wind and wave observations have been made in the Bay of Bengal (Glejin et al., 2013a; Nayak et al., 2013) and Arabian Sea (Aboobacker et al., 2011a; Glejin et al., 2013b); however, investigations of wind and waves in the waters south of Sri Lanka, which hosts one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world, are scarce. Although datasets from reanalysis projects (Semedo et al., 2010) and models (Sabique et al., 2012; Bhaskaran et al., 2014; Murty et al., 2014) are increasingly common, in situ observations (Rapizo et al., 2015) remain the most important reflections of the “true” ocean and atmosphere state. Therefore, most major developments in the marine and atmospheric sciences have been closely related to the development of in situ observations.
research objective: This study describes the survey, deployment, and measurements of wind and waves, with the aim of offering future users of the dataset the most comprehensive and as much information as possible. This dataset advances our understanding of the nearshore hydrodynamic processes and wave climate, including sea waves and swells, in the north Indian Ocean. Moreover, it is a valuable resource for ocean model parameterization and validation.
challenges: In these waters, simultaneous records of wind and wave data are sparse due to difficulties in deploying measurement instruments, although the area hosts one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world. There are significant errors in the measurements, especially for MWD. These could be caused by the complicated nearshore geometry and/or by the resolution of the large-scale ERA-Interim model, which is so low that it cannot describe changes in complex seabed terrain.
methods: The wind and wave dataset for Matara, Sri Lanka, consists of data obtained mainly from two different observation systems: the AWS and wave buoys. After rigorous quality control, the time series of wind, air pressure, and surface waves from the AWS, Buoy 1, and Buoy 2 were used to generate datasets with temporal resolutions of 30 min, 10 min, and 1 h, respectively. The main technical processes involved in generating the dataset are as follows: 1. calibration of all sensors, 2. transfer of a data in real time to a storage facility (to reduce or remove manual intervention), 3. error detection, 4. deviation testing and removal of records that deviate by > 3 standard deviations from the data mean. The data collected in southern Sri Lanka were taken from an integrated observation system that included the wave buoys (Buoy 1 and Buoy 2) and the AWSs (AWS1 and AWS2). Buoy 1, which was anchored at the bottom of the sea at a depth of 20 m in September 2013, was operated normally and continuously to collect water level and wave data for about 5 months. Buoy 2, which measured both wave and water level for 1 year from April 2013 to April 2014, consists of two instruments, a self-contained wave buoy at a depth of 10 m and a water level gauge. The seaside AWS (AWS1) was installed in December 2012 and can measure meteorological parameters, including wind speed and direction, air temperature, air humidity, and air pressure at an elevation of 12 m. In December 2015, the AWS was upgraded and moved approximately 5 m, with all sensors installed at an elevation of 1.5 m (AWS2).
dataset: We present a continuous in situ hydro-meteorology observational dataset from a set of instruments first deployed in December 2012 in the south of Sri Lanka, facing toward the north Indian Ocean. The archived dataset (Table 1) is examined in detail, including wave data at two locations with water depths of 20 and 10 m comprising synchronous time series of wind, ocean astronomical tide, air pressure, etc. The wind and wave dataset for Matara, Sri Lanka, consists of data obtained mainly from two different observation systems: the AWS and wave buoys. Buoy 1, which was anchored at the bottom of the sea at a depth of 20 m in September 2013, was operated normally and continuously to collect water level and wave data for about 5 months. Buoy 2, which measured both wave and water level for 1 year from April 2013 to April 2014, consists of two instruments, a self-contained wave buoy at a depth of 10 m and a water level gauge.
findings: Based on Buoy 2 data, the swells are the main component of waves year-round, although monsoons can markedly alter the proportion between swell and wind sea. The comparison of the reanalysis and measured Hs data shows a general mean correlation (correlation coefficient =0.747) with a general mean RMSE of 0.435 m during both years. Annually, 66.1 % of the waves are dominated by swells. Even though swells are predominant year-round, wind seas contribute sufficiently to the resultant waves during the SW (35.18 %) and NE (36.7 %) monsoon seasons. Waves from the south accounted for 69.12 % of all waves annually, mainly driven by swells, which predominate throughout the year. As a result, the wave climate in this area is controlled mainly by long swells.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting wind and wave data in busy shipping lanes?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in collecting wind and wave data in busy shipping lanes includes the sparse simultaneous records of wind and wave data due to difficulties in deploying measurement instruments. Additionally, significant errors can occur in measurements, especially for mean wave direction (MWD), due to complicated nearshore geometry and the low resolution of large-scale models like ERA-Interim.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that includes both wind and wave observations in a coastal region?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes both wind and wave observations is the continuous in situ hydro-meteorology observational dataset from instruments deployed in the south of Sri Lanka. This dataset includes wave data at two locations with water depths of 20 and 10 meters and consists of synchronous time series of wind, ocean astronomical tide, and air pressure.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'in situ observations' in the context of oceanographic data collection?
Definition.Answer: In situ observations refer to the direct measurement of ocean and atmospheric conditions using instruments placed in the environment, such as wave buoys and automatic weather stations (AWS), which provide the most accurate reflection of the actual state of the ocean and atmosphere.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods involving AWS and wave buoys in the southern Sri Lankan waters compare to other in situ ocean observation techniques used in different oceanic regions?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods in the southern Sri Lankan waters primarily use AWS and wave buoys to gather wind, air pressure, and surface wave data. These techniques involve calibration, real-time data transfer, and rigorous quality control, which are similar to other in situ observation methods. However, the unique challenges such as sparse data records and complex nearshore geometry require specific adjustments in these waters.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges of collecting wave data in regions with complex seabed terrain, and how might these challenges affect data reliability?
Interpretation.Answer: In regions with complex seabed terrain, significant errors in measurements, especially for Mean Wave Direction (MWD), may occur. These challenges could be due to the low resolution of large-scale models, which are unable to accurately describe changes in the seabed. The reliability of data is affected as the complicated nearshore geometry can introduce additional variability in wave data collection.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of multiple observational systems enhance the accuracy of wind and wave data collection, and what underlying rules can be drawn from the use of such systems in oceanographic research?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multiple observational systems, such as AWS and wave buoys, allows for comprehensive data collection across different parameters like wind speed, air pressure, and wave characteristics. This approach enhances accuracy by providing cross-validation opportunities and compensating for individual system limitations. It reflects an underlying rule in oceanographic research that diverse data sources can improve dataset reliability and robustness.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the temporal resolutions of different data collection methods have on the analysis of wave patterns, and how might these resolutions influence the interpretation of underlying ocean dynamics?
Interpretation.Answer: Different temporal resolutions, such as 30 min, 10 min, and 1 h intervals, allow researchers to capture varying aspects of wave patterns. Higher temporal resolution can reveal finer details of wave dynamics and transient events, while lower resolution may highlight broader trends. These resolutions influence the interpretation of ocean dynamics by determining the granularity of the observed data, which can affect the understanding of phenomena like swells and monsoon impacts on wave climate.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is in situ observation considered a crucial method for understanding ocean and atmospheric states in the context of the northern Indian Ocean?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In situ observations remain the most important reflections of the 'true' ocean and atmosphere state, providing data that are essential for model validation and data assimilation, especially in areas like the northern Indian Ocean where observational data are scarce.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the reliability of wave data collection in the southern seas of Sri Lanka, and how are these challenges addressed?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The reliability of wave data collection is ensured through rigorous quality control processes, including calibration of sensors, real-time data transfer to reduce manual intervention, error detection, and removal of records deviating significantly from the mean to address potential errors and ensure data accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes of deploying multiple observation systems like AWS and wave buoys in the context of wave and wind data collection in maritime regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Deploying multiple observation systems like AWS and wave buoys can enhance the comprehensiveness of wave and wind data collection, providing a more detailed and accurate dataset for understanding nearshore hydrodynamic processes and wave climate. This approach can help in ocean model parameterization and validation, and offer a more complete insight into maritime conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the challenges of deploying measurement instruments in busy shipping lanes affect the quality and reliability of ocean observational data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The challenges of deploying measurement instruments in busy shipping lanes can lead to sparse and potentially error-prone ocean observational data. Complex nearshore geometry and low-resolution models may introduce measurement errors, especially in parameters like Mean Wave Direction (MWD), affecting the reliability of the data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating real-time data transfer and error detection in the process of data collection for wave and wind observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating real-time data transfer and error detection in wave and wind observation data collection can significantly enhance data accuracy and reliability by reducing manual intervention. It allows for immediate identification and correction of anomalies, helping to maintain the integrity of the dataset and improve its usability for subsequent analyses and applications.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind deploying in situ observation systems in the waters south of Sri Lanka for wave and wind data collection?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to advance the understanding of nearshore hydrodynamic processes and wave climate, including sea waves and swells, in the north Indian Ocean. Additionally, the data is valuable for ocean model parameterization and validation, and for ensuring the safety of shipping lanes in a region that hosts one of the busiest maritime routes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals are pursued by implementing rigorous quality control measures in the collection of oceanographic data using pressure sensors and buoys?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals pursued by implementing rigorous quality control measures include ensuring the reliability and accuracy of the data collected, which is vital for analyzing oceanographic characteristics, improving the safety of maritime operations, and contributing to disaster assessment along the maritime silk road. Quality control helps maintain data integrity by removing anomalies and errors that could skew analyses and interpretations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be followed to ensure the reliability and quality control of wave data collected from oceanic observation systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection method involves quality control measures such as calibration of sensors, real-time data transfer to reduce manual errors, error detection, and removal of records that deviate by more than three standard deviations from the data mean. This ensures data reliability and accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can integrated observation systems be structured to efficiently collect wind and wave data in challenging maritime environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An integrated observation system can include wave buoys and automated weather stations (AWS) placed strategically, such as at different depths in the ocean and onshore, to gather comprehensive data. Calibration of instruments and real-time data transfer are crucial to minimize errors and maintain continuity in data collection.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the reliable collection of wave and tidal data in regions with complex seabed terrain, such as the southern waters of Sri Lanka?
Enablement.Answer: The use of pressure-type sensors deployed on the seabed and wave buoys anchored at specific depths have enabled reliable data collection. These instruments are calibrated and undergo quality control measures, such as error detection and deviation testing, to ensure data accuracy despite the complex seabed terrain.

Enablement.Question: How do integrated observation systems enhance the collection of wind and wave data in busy shipping lanes in the northern Indian Ocean?
Enablement.Answer: Integrated observation systems, which combine wave buoys and automatic weather stations (AWS), enhance data collection by providing synchronized measurements of wind, air pressure, and surface waves. These systems allow for continuous data acquisition even in busy shipping lanes, reducing manual intervention and ensuring data quality through real-time data transfer and rigorous quality control processes.

Enablement.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of ocean observational datasets used for model validation in the north Indian Ocean?
Enablement.Answer: To ensure accuracy and reliability, methods such as sensor calibration, real-time data transfer, error detection, and deviation testing are employed. Records deviating by more than three standard deviations from the mean are removed, and data is collected from integrated systems comprising wave buoys and AWS, capturing detailed temporal variations.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a limited availability of simultaneous wind and wave data records in oceanic regions with busy shipping lanes?
Expectation.Answer: Simultaneous records of wind and wave data are sparse due to difficulties in deploying measurement instruments in busy shipping lanes. The presence of significant errors in measurements, especially for MWD, could also be attributed to the complicated nearshore geometry and the low resolution of large-scale models that fail to capture changes in complex seabed terrain.

Expectation.Question: Why do oceanographic models still rely heavily on in situ observations despite the availability of reanalysis datasets?
Expectation.Answer: In situ observations remain the most important reflections of the 'true' ocean and atmosphere state. They are crucial for model validation and parameterization as they provide accurate and direct measurements that reanalysis datasets and models, which can have limitations in resolution and accuracy, may not capture comprehensively.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in expanding the existing observational datasets for the southern Sri Lankan wave studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges include the difficulties of deploying measurement instruments due to busy shipping lanes, significant errors, especially in MWD measurements caused by complex seabed terrain, and the need for high-resolution models to accurately describe these changes.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways might integrating additional observational technologies enhance the understanding of wave characteristics in the region?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating additional observational technologies, such as higher-resolution sensors or advanced remote sensing techniques, could enhance the understanding of wave characteristics by providing more accurate and comprehensive data. This integration could help address errors and limitations associated with current methods, offering better model validation and parameterization opportunities.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore various data collection methods for obtaining wave and wind data in the southern Indian Ocean, particularly off the coast of Sri Lanka.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for obtaining wave and wind data in the southern Indian Ocean, particularly off the coast of Sri Lanka, include deploying wave buoys and AWS (Automatic Weather Stations). The wave buoys, such as Buoy 1 and Buoy 2, are anchored at specific depths (20m and 10m respectively) to measure water level and wave data. AWS are used to measure meteorological parameters like wind speed and direction, air temperature, humidity, and air pressure.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the challenges faced during the deployment and operation of oceanic data collection instruments in the southern waters near Sri Lanka.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges faced during the deployment and operation of oceanic data collection instruments in the southern waters near Sri Lanka include the scarcity of simultaneous wind and wave data due to difficulties in instrument deployment. Significant measurement errors, especially in Mean Wave Direction (MWD), are noted. These errors could be attributed to the complex nearshore geometry and low resolution of large-scale models that fail to capture changes in seabed terrain.
